Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for Logic Mentoring Workshop 2019 (LMW)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will enable students to attend the Logic Mentoring Workshop (LMW 2019) which will be co-located with the International Conference on Logic in Computer Science (LICS) to be held in July in Vancouver, British Columbia. LICS is the flagship conference in logic and semantics. LMW seeks to introduce and mentor students who have already shown interest in logic and semantics research by bringing them to LICS so they can learn about current research problems, make connections with their contemporaries, and interact with leaders in the field.

Funded students will benefit greatly from the opportunity to engage in the critical technical, professional, and social exchanges that both conferences foster. The LMW workshop will focus on mentoring and career advice to enable undergraduate and graduate students, and especially women, and underrepresented minorities to pursue and thrive in research careers both in logic/semantics specifically and in computer science generally. This travel grant will enable career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer science researchers. Students have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class researchers, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 4th Logic Mentoring Workshop (LMW) took place on June 22, 2019, as a satellite event of the ACM/IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science (LICS) in Vancouver, Canada.  LICS is the flagship conference in computational logic and one of the premier conferences in all of theoretical computer science. It is a crucial meeting for students working in the area of logics, since it offers an opportunity to present their own work and initiate contacts that may lead, e.g., to research collaborations, job positions, research visits, etc. However, for students that are new in the field and know none of the other conference participants, the atmosphere can be intimidating. The purpose of the workshop is to motivate undergraduate and graduate students to pursue a research career, either in academia or in industry. In particular, LMW intends to promote the representation of women and minorities in the community, and more generally in computer science.  The workshop aims at overcoming uncertainties and giving participants confidence with respect to their research career. Bringing them together with more senior researchers gives them practical examples and advice on how to act at a conference and what they should and should not do in order to achieve their career goals.

The workshop program comprised a get-to-know-each-other session and a number of talks from leaders and rising stars in the community, as well as a panel session. The get-to-know-each-other-session was the first opportunity for participants to interact and to ask questions and served well to open discussions about personal uncertainties. The talks covered a variety of topics, partially of a philosophical nature, partially technical as often happens at conferences, partially regarding practical topics such as advice for talk preparation and how to find ideas for research projects. The intention of these talks was to give the participants an insight into the role of logic research and what its practice constitutes over the course of a career. The panel session provided an opportunity for the participants to pose their own questions to a selection of researchers at various points in their career. Chaired by the organisers, who selected certain topics in advance, it was a vibrant and interactive discussion which exposed the students to issues surrounding logic research and academia, offering several differing viewpoints therein. After the workshop, the organisers collected and uploaded all talk slides, in order to make them permanently available to everyone. The full programme is given below. Further details may be found at https://lics.siglog.org/lics19/lmw.php.

LMW 2019 had 26 registered participants. Since the parallel workshops were held in adjacent rooms, participants could move easily between the workshops and, at times, the number of people present in the room was around 35. A total of 18 students were offered (partial) expense reimbursements for participating, thanks to sponsorship from NSF, Amazon, Galois, and ACM/SIGLOG. Due to the positive reception, the workshop was renewed for further editions.

Full Program

  • Ana Sokolova: On Coalgebra, Loving What You Do, and Doing Beautiful Science
  • Get-to-Know-Each Other and Find a Conference Buddy
  • Favonia: Introduction to Cubical Type Theory 
  • Ohad Kammar: Where do ideas come from?
  • ?tienne Miquey: Sequent calculus and their computational content
  • Sylvain Schmitz: Well-quasi-orders in Logic 
  • Brigitte Pientka: How to give a talk
  • Bob Atkey: Reviewing
  • Panel with Favonia, Ohad Kammar, Brigitte Pientka, Ana Sokolova
